Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploiting carbon and nitrogen compounds for energy positive wastewater treatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1632019
Gude

Wastewater treatment and nutrient removal schemes are energy-intensive. This research provides an innovative solution to integrate new microbial systems to develop energy-positive wastewater treatment and desalination. A key objective of this research is to use microbes in an electrochemical cell to remove nitrogen compounds at one electrode (the cathode) and to oxidize carbon compounds at the other electrode (the anode). This EAGER project focuses on the feasibility of using bacteria as a catalyst at the cathode. If successful, the results of this project could guide the design of electrochemical cells that would simultaneously remove pollutants from wastewater, desalinate brackish water, and produce electrical energy.

A wide range of encouraging advancements of various bioelectrochemical systems for water treatment have recently been reported. A major challenge is to determine the rate limiting relationships between the bioelectrochemical processes in the bioanode and biocathode biofilms. This EAGER project has the following goals: 1) Discover and establish an energy-positive synergistic relationship between bioanode and anerobic ammonium oxidation (anammox) biocathode processes in microbial desalination cells; 2) Evaluate the performance of anammox bacteria in a bioelectrochemical cell and study the growth kinetics and nitrogen removal capabilities to correlate microbiological parameters with environmental factors and process performance; and 3) Provide research and education opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students from underrepresented groups and provide outreach to the broader community. The transformative aspect of this project is integrating tertiary wastewater treatment and desalination processes, coupled with concurrent electricity production inspired by bioelectrochemical principles. To overcome the major challenges for the most envisioned applications of microbial desalination cells, this research capitalizes on anammox biocathode development and integrates powerful high-throughput molecular sequencing, advanced process characterization, and electrochemical impedance tools to develop energy-positive integrated wastewater-desalination systems. This project has the potential for wider applications in reclaiming high quality effluents from municipal, agricultural and industrial wastewaters combined with desalination. This EAGER project is enriched by interdisciplinary research activities among electrochemistry, molecular biology, microbiology, environmental and chemical engineering disciplines and positively impacts K-12 students, especially motivating them toward STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wastewater treatment systems need to become energy-independent to be sustainable and to meet increasing future sanitation needs. Current aeration based wastewater treatment technologies are resource demanding and release carbon dioxide and nutrients into the environment. Bioelectrochemical principle based microbial desalination process can convert organic wastes directly into clean electricity (high value, carbon-neutral energy) from wastewaters while desalinating saline waters. However, the major challenge in this process is the electron transfer in cathode chambers. A significant knowledge gap exists in understanding the cathodic electron transfer mediated by biological microbial catalysts, anammmox biofilms. Microbial desalination cells provide unique opportunities through biocathodes to resolve the present environmental remediation needs of wastewater treatment, especially, nitrogen removal and its reuse and by recovery of pre-treated water from high hardness and saline water sources.

 In this research, we have explored the possibility of utilizing beneficial bacteria such as anammox (anaerobic ammonia oxidizing) bacteria for energy-positive advanced wastewater treatment in a biological process configuration which allows for simultaneous water and energy recovery along with nutrient removal. A series of experimental studies were conducted to develop this bioelectrochemical system to prove the proof-of-concept and then understand the effect of various parameters that could possibly affect this process. Experimental studies were conducted under aerobic, anaerobic and anoxic conditions to determine which configuration yields the best results in terms of water treatment, energy recovery and desalination potentials. Simulated and actual wastewater samples from a local wastewater treatment plant were used in the process to evaluate the potential of this novel scientific concept. Results from this study show that an energy-yielding nutrient removal scheme can be developed by utilizing resource-efficient and environmentally-friendly microbial biofilms that produce electricity from organic and nutrient compounds (pollutants) present in municipal wastewater. This project has provided opportunities and or funding support for two graduate students and four undergraduate students who have presented their research outcomes at regional and national/international conferences. This project also allowed for purchase of an equipment for research. Other outcomes include three research journal articles. We have also developed new research collaborations with USDA-ARS research facility in South Carolina.
